topic_page.title: Muscle & Recovery

intro.what_this_topic_means: This topic covers recovery-related physiology: soreness, repair signaling, adaptation to training, sleep-driven recovery, and the difference between perceived recovery and actual tissue remodeling.
common_misconceptions: More soreness does not always mean more growth.
Faster recovery is not always better if it masks overload.
Animal or mechanistic evidence is not the same as proven human benefit.
who_should_be_extra_cautious: Adolescents and young athletes (developmental setpoints are still calibrating)
People with endocrine disorders or unexplained fatigue
People with significant psychiatric vulnerability if a compound affects sleep/mood

how_to_use_this_page: Topics help you browse; they do not recommend peptides.
Always check status and risk score first.
Human evidence and preclinical evidence are separated.

peptides.why_people_look_it_up: Frequently discussed in fitness contexts related to body composition and recovery interest; association reflects user interest, not endorsement.

safety_callouts.title: Adolescents and development
safety_callouts.body: If you are under 18, assume uncertainty is part of the risk. Many compounds have little to no adolescent data, and endocrine/metabolic effects may have long-lived consequences.

evidence_notes.title: Why evidence changes
evidence_notes.body: Status and evidence can change quickly as trials publish or regulators update labeling. This app logs updates and ties key claims to specific sources.
